ingredients: 1 large, ripe tomato, cored and quartered
1 large red bell pepper, seeded and roughly chopped
½ teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
steps: Combine tomato, red bell pepper, habanero pepper, fresno chili, garlic, ginger, and water in a blender for the sauce.
Heat olive oil in a saucepan over medium heat.
Add onion and salt and sauté until onion starts to soften, 4 to 5 minutes.
Clear space in the middle of the pan, add tomato paste, and sauté for 2 to 3 minutes.
Season with paprika, curry powder, cumin, thyme, pepper, and turmeric.
Continue cooking for 1 to 2 minutes until everything is well combined.
Turn off the heat, and stir in the rice, making sure every grain of rice is coated with the oil-tomato mixture.
Add bay leaf and chicken bouillon paste.
Turn heat to high, stir in tomato sauce, and bring to a vigorous simmer.
Cover with a tight fitting lid, reduce heat to medium-low, and simmer for 20 minutes. Do not remove the lid or stir rice.
Turn off heat after 20 minutes, and set the timer for 12 minutes. Allow rice to sit and do not remove the lid.
After the 12 minutes are up, remove lid, and fluff rice with a fork, separating all the grains. Serve garnished with green onions and chopped cilantro.

ingredients: ½ teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
1 tablespoon wine vinegar or apple cider vinegar
steps: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Heat olive oil and butter in a large oven-proof skillet over medium heat. Add onions and salt; cook until beginning to soften and turn translucent, 3 to 5 minutes.
Stir in curry powder, cumin, turmeric, black pepper, and oregano; cook for 1 to 2 minutes.
Add ground beef and cook while breaking into small crumbles. Add one bay leaf, tomato paste, and garlic; cook for another 2 minutes.
Stir in lemon juice, lemon zest, vinegar, Worcestershire sauce, and chutney. Smooth the top and simmer gently for 5 minutes.
In a bowl, soak bread in 1/2 cup milk for 5 minutes. Squeeze out excess milk and add soaked bread to the meat mixture, mashing to combine.
Mix remaining milk with eggs and a pinch of salt; whisk together and pour over the meat. Top with the remaining bay leaves.
Bake until the custard topping is set and lightly golden, about 45 minutes.
Let rest for 5 minutes before serving.

ingredients: 1 (3 pound) whole chicken, cut into 1-inch pieces
steps: Soak the chicken in 2 cups water and lemon juice for 10 minutes; drain.
Place the onion in a heavy pot over medium-high heat and cook, stirring, until very dark, about 20 minutes.
Stir in butter, cayenne pepper, paprika, black pepper, and ginger; add 1 more cup of water.
Add the drained chicken and stir to combine. Cover and reduce heat to low; simmer until chicken is tender, about 1 hour.
If desired, whisk flour with 2 tablespoons water and stir into the pot to thicken; simmer about 2 minutes.
Stir in the hard-cooked eggs and cook until heated through, about 10 minutes more.

ingredients: 1 pound collard greens (or kale), washed and stems removed
½ teaspoon curry powder or turmeric
steps: Heat oil in a medium-large skillet, add onions and garlic, and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add tomatoes, curry powder, coriander, and paprika; stir with a heavy spoon for about 2 minutes.
Add minced meat and bouillon powder; stir and simmer for about 5 minutes.
Add chopped collards, cayenne pepper, and lemon juice; continue cooking for another 5–10 minutes until flavors blend and greens reach preferred doneness.
Adjust seasonings to taste; remove from heat and serve (often with ugali, chapati, or rice).
notes: Don’t overcook—the greens should be tender yet slightly crisp.

ingredients: 6–8 green bananas (matoke), peeled and cut into chunks
2 medium tomatoes, chopped (or 2 tbsp tomato paste)
Fresh cilantro or parsley for garnish (optional)
steps: Peel green bananas, cut into 1–2 inch chunks, and soak in salted water to prevent browning.
Heat oil in a pot or skillet over medium heat.
Add onion and sauté for 3–4 minutes until golden; add garlic and ginger (if using) and cook for another minute.
Stir in tomatoes (or tomato paste) and bell pepper; cook for 3–5 minutes until tomatoes soften.
Add turmeric and coriander (if using), stirring briefly to release flavors. Season with salt and pepper.
Add matoke chunks and gently stir to coat with the spice-tomato base.
Pour in water or broth—enough to mostly cover the matoke. Bring to a gentle boil, reduce heat to low, then cover and simmer for 25–30 minutes until the matoke is tender and the stew thickens.
Adjust seasoning if necessary.
Garnish with cilantro or parsley and serve (commonly with rice, ugali, or chapati).
notes: Green bananas should be soft but not mushy. Add more water if the stew gets too dry.

ingredients: ¾ cup egusi seeds or pumpkin seeds
2 pounds fresh shrimp, peeled and deveined
1 pound fresh spinach, washed and chopped
steps: Place seeds in a blender; blend until mixture is powdery, 30 to 40 seconds.
Cut beef into bite-sized cubes; season with salt.
Heat oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Cook beef in hot oil until brown but not cooked through, 3 to 5 minutes.
Place tomatoes, onion, and peppers in a blender; blend until smooth, about 30 seconds. Stir tomato mixture into beef; reduce heat to medium-low and cover. Cook until meat is tender, 40 to 50 minutes.
Add shrimp, tomato sauce, water, and tomato paste; simmer for 10 minutes.
Stir in spinach and powdered seeds. Continue simmering for 10 more minutes.

ingredients: 200 g cocoyam, mashed for thickening soup
A handful of ukazi leaves, thinly sliced
steps: Season the meat with pepper, onion, 2 seasoning cubes and salt. Place on heat and cook till it is soft.
Add the stockfish and dried fish and cook for about 10 minutes.
Ensure you have about 6 cups of stock in the pot.
Add the periwinkle and palm oil to the stock and let the heat dissolve the oil.
Add your thickener (cocoyam or achi) and cook for about 15 minutes to let it thicken.
Add the okazi leaves, crayfish and the remaining seasoning cube.
Stir properly and cook for another 15 minutes.
Add salt to taste and serve.
Sauté onion and garlic until fragrant.
Add meat and brown on all sides.
Stir in tomatoes and cook for a few minutes.
Add peanut butter and water/stock; stir until smooth.
Add vegetables (cabbage, carrots); simmer until meat and vegetables are tender.
Season to taste and serve with rice or fufu.
Heat oil and sauté onion until soft.
Add garlic, ginger, and spices; cook until fragrant.
Add peppers, carrots, and tomato; stir and cook for 5 minutes.
Add baked beans, salt, and sugar; simmer for another 5 minutes.
Serve warm or cold alongside pap, bread, or grilled meats.
Boil maize and beans in a pot until tender.
Heat oil in a sufuria, then sauté onion and garlic until golden.
Add courgette, green pepper, ginger, coriander, and cumin; stir and cook briefly.
Add chillies, tomatoes, and salt; stir and let tomatoes soften.
Mix in boiled maize and beans; combine well and simmer for 1–2 minutes.
Optionally, add a splash of water, bring to gentle boil, and serve hot.
notes: A staple meal from Kenya’s central region—simple, nutritious, and flavorful.

ingredients: ½–1 cup coconut milk (or regular milk)
steps: Mix flour, sugar, salt, and baking powder in a bowl.
Whisk in egg and coconut milk to form a soft dough.
Knead lightly and roll out dough to ~½-inch thickness.
Cut into triangles or circles.
Heat oil in a skillet; fry mandazi until golden on both sides, about 1–2 minutes per side.
Drain on paper towels and serve warm.
notes: Also known as Swahili bun or puff-puff; a popular East African snack or breakfast treat.
